3.1: Weep every Venus, and all Cupids wail,

3.3: Dead is the Sparrow of my girl, the joy,
3.4: Sparrow, my sweeting's most delicious toy,
3.5: Whom loved she dearer than her very eyes;
3.6: For he was honeyed-pet and anywise
3.7: Knew her, as even she her mother knew;
3.8: Ne'er from her bosom's harbourage he flew
3.9: But 'round her hopping here, there, everywhere,

3.11: Now must he wander o'er the darkling way
3.12: Thither, whence life-return the Fates denay.

3.14: In Orcus ever loveliest things devouring:

3.18: With turgid eyelids tinted rose by tears.

5.1: Love we (my Lesbia!) and live we our day,

5.4: The Suns can westward sink again to rise
5.5: But we, extinguished once our tiny light,
5.6: Perforce shall slumber through one lasting night!
5.7: Kiss me a thousand times, then hundred more,
5.8: Then thousand others, then a new five-score,
5.9: Still other thousand other hundred store.
5.10: Last when the sums to many thousands grow,
5.11: The tale let's trouble till no more we know,
5.12: Nor envious wight despiteful shall misween us
5.13: Knowing how many kisses have been kissed between us.

17.1: Colony! fain to display thy games on length of thy town-bridge!

17.9: Hurlèd head over heels precipitous whelmed in the quagmire,
17.10: Where the lake and the boglands are most rotten and stinking,
17.11: Deepest and lividest lie, the swallow of hollow voracious.
17.12: Witless surely the wight whose sense is less than of boy-babe
17.13: Two-year-old and a-sleep on trembling forearm of father.
17.14: He though, wedded to girl in greenest bloom of her youth-tide,
17.15: (Bride-wife daintier bred than ever was delicate kidlet,
17.16: Worthier diligent watch than grape-bunch blackest and ripest)
17.17: Suffers her sport as she please nor rates her even at hair's worth,
17.18: Nowise 'stirring himself, but lying log-like as alder
17.19: Felled and o'er floating the fosse of safe Ligurian woodsman,
17.20: Feeling withal, as though such spouse he never had own'd;
17.21: So this marvel o' mine sees naught, and nothing can hear he,
17.22: What he himself, an he be or not be, wholly unknowing.
17.23: Now would I willingly pitch such wight head first fro' thy bridge,
17.24: Better a-sudden t'arouse that numskull's stolid old senses,
17.25: Or in the sluggish mud his soul supine to deposit
17.26: Even as she-mule casts iron shoe where quagmire is stiffest.

18.1: This grove to thee devote I give, Priapus!

19.1: This place, O youths, I protect, nor less this turfbuilded cottage,
19.2: Roofed with its osier-twigs and thatched with its bundles of sedges;
19.3: I from the dried oak hewn and fashioned with rustical hatchet,
19.4: Guarding them year by year while more are they evermore thriving.
19.5: For here be owners twain who greet and worship my Godship,
19.6: He of the poor hut lord and his son, the pair of them peasants:
19.7: This with assiduous toil aye works the thicketty herbage
19.8: And the coarse water-grass to clear afar from my chapel:
19.9: That with his open hand ever brings me offerings humble.
19.10: Hung up in honour mine are flowery firstlings of spring-tide,
19.11: Wreaths with their ears still soft the tender stalklets a-crowning;
19.12: Violets pale are mine by side of the poppy-head pallid;
19.13: With the dull yellow gourd and apples sweetest of savour;
19.14: Lastly the blushing grape disposed in shade of the vine-tree.
19.15: Anon mine altar (this same) with blood (but you will be silent!)
19.16: Bearded kid and anon some horny-hoofed nanny shall sprinkle.
19.17: Wherefore Priapus is bound to requite such honours by service,
19.18: Doing his duty to guard both vineyard and garth of his lordling.
19.19: Here then, O lads, refrain from ill-mannered picking and stealing:
19.20: Rich be the neighbour-hind and negligent eke his Priapus:
19.21: Take what be his: this path hence leadeth straight to his ownings.

20.8: Then with green vine-shoot and the luscious bunch,
20.9: And glaucous olive-tree in bitter cold.
20.10: The dainty she-goat from my pasture bears
20.11: Her milk-distended udders to the town:
20.12: Out of my sheep-cotes ta'en the fatted lamb
20.13: Sends home with silver right-hand heavily charged;
20.14: And, while its mother lows, the tender calf
20.15: Before the temples of the Gods must bleed.
20.16: Hence of such Godhead, (traveller !) stand in awe,

20.18: Thy cross is ready, shaped as artless yard;
20.20: The boor, and plucking forth with bended arm
20.21: Makes of this tool a club for doughty hand.

30.5: When heed'st thou not deserting me (Sad me!) in sorest scathe,
30.6: Ah say whate'er shall humans do? in whom shall man show faith?
30.7: For sure thou bad'st me safely yield my spirit (wretch!) to thee,

62.1: Vesper is here, O youths, rise all; for Vesper Olympus
62.2: Scales and in fine enfires what lights so long were expected!
62.3: Time 'tis now to arise, now leave we tables rich laden,

62.5: Hymen O Hymenaeus: Hymen here, O Hymenaeus!
62.6: View ye the Youths, O Maids unwed? Then rise to withstand them:
62.7: Doubtless the night-fraught Star displays his splendour Oetean.
62.8: Sooth 'tis so; d'ye sight how Speedily sprang they to warfare?
62.9: Nor for a naught up-sprang: they'll Sing what need we to conquer.
62.10: Hymen O Hymenaeus: Hymen here, O Hymenaeus!
62.11: Nowise easy the palm for us (Companions!) be proffer'd,
62.12: Lo! now the maidens muse and meditate matter of forethought
62.13: Nor meditate they in vain; they muse a humorous something.
62.14: Yet naught wonder it is, their sprites be wholly in labour.
62.15: We bear divided thought one way and hearing in other:
62.16: Vanquish't by right we must be, since Victory loveth the heedful.
62.17: Therefore at least d'ye turn your minds the task to consider,
62.18: Soon shall begin their say whose countersay shall befit you.

62.22: Tear from a parent's clasp her child despite of her clinging
62.23: And upon love-hot youth bestowest her chastest of maidenhoods!

62.25: Hymen O Hymenaeus, Hymen here, O Hymenaeus!
62.26: Hesperus! say what flame more gladsome in Heavens be shining?
62.27: Thou whose light makes sure long-pledged connubial promise
62.28: Plighted erewhile by men and erstwhile plighted by parents.
62.29: Yet to be ne'er fulfilled before thy fire's ardours have risen!

62.34: Hymen O Hymenaeus, Hymen here, O Hymenaeus!
