62.39: Pleases the bevy unwed with feigned complaints to accuse thee.
62.40: What if assail they whom their souls in secrecy cherish?
62.41: Hymen O Hymenaeus, Hymen here, O Hymenaeus!
62.42: E'en as a flow'ret born secluded in garden enclosed,
62.43: Unto the flock unknown and ne'er uptorn by the ploughshare,
62.44: Soothed by the zephyrs and strengthened by suns and nourish't by showers
62.46: Loves her many a youth and longs for her many a maiden:
62.47: Yet from her lissome stalk when cropt that flower deflowered,
62.48: Loves her never a youth nor longs for her ever a maiden:
62.49: Thus while the virgin be whole, such while she's the dearling of kinsfolk;
62.50: Yet no sooner is lost her bloom from body polluted,
62.51: Neither to youths she is joy, nor a dearling she to the maidens.
62.52: Hymen O Hymenaeus, Hymen here, O Hymenaeus!
62.53: E'en as an unmated vine which born in field of the barest
62.54: Never upraises head nor breeds the mellowy grape-bunch,
62.55: But under weight prone-bowed that tender body a-bending
62.56: Makes she her root anon to touch her topmost of tendrils;
62.57: Tends her never a hind nor tends her ever a herdsman:
62.58: Yet if haply conjoined the same with elm as a husband,
62.59: Tends her many a hind and tends her many a herdsman:
62.60: Thus is the maid when whole, uncultured waxes she aged;
62.61: But whenas union meet she wins her at ripest of seasons,
62.62: More to her spouse she is dear and less she's irk to her parents.
62.63: Hymen O Hymenaeus, Hymen here, O Hymenaeus!
62.64: But do thou cease to resist (O Maid!) such bridegroom opposing,
62.65: Right it is not to resist whereto consigned thee a father,
62.66: Father and mother of thee unto whom obedience is owing.
62.67: Not is that maidenhood all thine own, but partly thy parents!
62.68: Owneth thy sire one third, one third is right of thy mother,
62.69: Only the third is thine: stint thee to strive with the others,
62.70: Who to the stranger son have yielded their dues with a dower!
62.71: Hymen O Hymenaeus: Hymen here, O Hymenaeus!

63.1: O'er high deep seas in speedy ship his voyage Atys sped
63.2: Until he trod the Phrygian grove with hurried eager tread
63.3: And as the gloomy tree-shorn stead, the she-god's home, he sought
63.4: There sorely stung with fiery ire and madman's vaguing thought,
63.5: Share he with sharpened flint the freight wherewith his form was fraught.
63.6: Then as the she-he sensed limbs were void of manly strain
63.7: And sighted freshly shed a-ground spot of ensanguined stain,
63.8: Snatched she the timbrel's legier load with hands as snowdrops white,
63.9: Thy timbrel, Mother Cybele, the firstings of thy rite,
63.10: And as her tender finger-tips on bull-back hollow rang
63.11: She rose a-grieving and her song to listening comrades sang.
63.12: "Up Gallae, hie together, haste for Cybele's deep grove,
63.13: Hie to the Dindymnean dame, ye flocks that love to rove;
63.14: The which affecting stranger steads as bound in exile's brunt
63.15: My sect pursuing led by me have nerved you to confront
63.16: The raging surge of salty sea and ocean's tyrant hand
63.17: As your hate of Venus' hest your manly forms unmann'd,
63.18: Gladden your souls, ye mistresses, with sense of error bann'd.
63.19: Drive from your spirits dull delay, together follow ye
63.20: To hold of Phrygian goddess, home of Phrygian Cybebe,
63.21: Where  loud the cymbal's voice resounds with timbrel-echoes blending,
63.22: And where the Phrygian piper drones grave bass from reed a-bending,
63.23: Where toss their ivy-circled heads with might the Maenades
63.24: Where ply mid shrilly lullilooes the holiest mysteries,
63.25: Where to fly here and there be wont the she-god's vaguing train,
63.26: Thither behoves us lead the dance in quick-step hasty strain."
63.27: Soon as had Atys (bastard-she) this lay to comrades sung
63.28: The Chorus sudden lulliloos with quivering, quavering tongue,
63.29: Again the nimble timbrel groans, the scooped-out cymbals clash,
63.30: And up green Ida flits the Choir, with footsteps hurrying rash
63.31: Then Atys frantic, panting, raves, a-wandering, lost, insane,
63.32: And leads with timbrel hent and treads the shades where shadows rain,
63.33: Like heifer spurning load of yoke in yet unbroken pride;
63.34: And the swift Gallae follow fain their first and fleet-foot guide.
63.35: But when the home of Cybele they make with toil out-worn
63.36: O'er much, they lay them down to sleep and gifts of Ceres scorn;
63.37: Till heavy slumbers seal their eyelids langourous, drooping lowly,
63.38: And raving frenzy flies each brain departing softly, slowly.
63.39: But when Dan Sol with radiant eyes that fire his face of gold
63.40: Surveyed white aether and solid soil and waters uncontrol'd,
63.41: And chased with steeds sonorous-hooved the shades of lingering night,
63.42: Then sleep from waking Atys fled fleeting with sudden flight,
63.43: By Nymph Pasithae welcomed to palpitating breast.
63.44: Thus when his frenzy raging rash was soothed to gentlest rest,
63.45: Atys revolved deeds lately done, as thought from breast unfolding,
63.46: And what he'd lost and what he was with lucid sprite beholding,
63.47: To shallows led by surging soul again the way 'gan take.
63.48: There casting glance of weeping eyes where vasty billows brake,
63.49: Sad-voiced in pitifullest lay his native land bespake.
63.50: "Country of me, Creatress mine, born to thee and bred,
63.51: By hapless me abandoned as by thrall from lordling fled,
63.52: When me to Ida's groves and glades these vaguing footsteps bore
63.53: To tarry 'mid the snows and where lurk beasts in antres frore
63.54: And seek the deeply hidden lairs where furious ferals meet!
63.55: Where, Country! whither placed must I now hold thy site and seat?
63.56: Lief would these balls of eyes direct to thee their line of sight,
63.57: Which for a while, a little while, would free me from despite.
63.58: Must I for ever roam these groves from house and home afar?
63.59: Of country, parents, kith and kin (life's boon) myself debar?
63.60: Fly Forum, fly  Palestra, fly the Stadium, the Gymnase?
63.61: Wretch, ah poor wretch, I'm doomed (my soul!) to mourn throughout my days,
63.62: For what of form or figure is, which I failed to enjoy?
63.63: I full-grown man, I blooming youth, I stripling, I a boy,
63.64: I of Gymnasium erst the bloom, I too of oil the pride:
63.65: Warm was my threshold, ever stood my gateways opening wide,
63.66: My house was ever garlanded and hung with flowery freight,
63.67: And couch to quit with rising sun, has ever been my fate:
63.68: Now must I Cybele's she-slave, priestess of gods, be hight?
63.69: I Maenad I, mere bit of self, I neutral barren wight?
63.70: I spend my life-tide couch't beneath high-towering Phrygian peaks?
63.71: I dwell on Ida's verdant slopes mottled with snowy streaks,
63.72: Where homes the forest-haunting doe, where roams the wildling boar?
63.73: Now, now I rue my deed foredone, now, now it irks me sore!"
63.74: Whenas from out those roseate lips these accents rapid flew,
63.75: Bore them to ears divine consigned a Nuncio true and new;
63.76: Then Cybele her lions twain disjoining from their yoke
63.77: The left-hand enemy of the herds a-goading thus bespoke:
63.78: "Up feral fell! up, hie with him, see rage his foot-steps urge,
63.79: See that his fury smite him till he seek the forest verge,
63.80: He who with over-freedom fain would fly mine empery.
63.81: Go, slash thy flank with lashing tail and sense the strokes of thee,
63.82: Make the whole mountain to thy roar sound and resound again,
63.83: And fiercely toss thy brawny neck that bears the tawny mane!"
63.84: So quoth an angered Cybele, and yoke with hand untied:
63.85: The feral rose in fiery wrath and self-inciting hied,
63.86: A-charging, roaring through the brake with breaking paws he tore.
63.87: But when he reached the humid sands where surges cream the shore,
63.88: Spying soft Atys lingering near the marbled pave of sea
63.89: He springs: the terror-madded wretch back to the wood doth flee,
63.90: Where for the remnant of her days a bondmaid's life led she.
63.91: Great Goddess, Goddess Cybele, Dindymus dame divine,
63.92: Far from my house and home thy wrath and wrack, dread mistress mine:
63.93: Goad others on with Fury's goad, others to Ire consign!

64.1: Pine-trees gendered whilome upon soaring Peliac summit
64.2: Swam (as the tale is told) through liquid surges of Neptune
64.3: Far as the Phasis-flood and frontier-land Aeetean;
64.4: Whenas the youths elect, of Argive vigour the oak-heart,
64.5: Longing the Golden Fleece of the Colchis-region to harry,
64.6: Dared in a poop swift-paced to span salt seas and their shallows,
64.7: Sweeping the deep blue seas with sweeps a-carven of fir-wood.
64.8: She, that governing Goddess of citadels crowning the cities,
64.9: Builded herself their car fast-flitting with lightest of breezes,
64.10: Weaving plants of the pine conjoined in curve of the kelson;
64.11: Foremost of all to imbue rude Amphitrite with ship-lore.
64.12: Soon as her beak had burst through wind-rackt spaces of ocean,
64.13: While the oar-tortured wave with spumy whiteness was blanching,
64.14: Surged from the deep abyss and hoar-capped billows the faces
64.15: Seaborn, Nereids eyeing the  prodigy wonder-smitten.
64.16: There too mortal orbs through softened spendours regarded
64.17: Ocean-nymphs who exposed bodies denuded of raiment
64.18: Bare to the breast upthrust from hoar froth capping the sea-depths.
64.19: Then Thetis Peleus fired (men say) a-sudden with love,
64.20: Then Thetis nowise spurned to mate and marry with mortal,
64.21: Then Thetis' Sire himself her yoke with Peleus sanctioned.
64.22: Oh, in those happier days now fondly yearned-for, you heroes
64.23: Born; (all hail!) of the gods begotten, and excellent issue
64.24: Bred by your mothers, all hail! and placid deal me your favour.
64.25: Oft with the sound of me, in strains and spells I'll invoke you;
64.26: You too by wedding-torch so happily, highly augmented,
64.27: Peleus, Thessaly's ward, in whose favor Jupiter himself,
64.28: The Father of the gods, resigned his passions.
64.29: You Thetis, fairest of maids Nereian, vouchsafed to marry?
64.30: You did Tethys empower to woo and wed with her grandchild;
64.31: Nor less Oceanus, with water compassing th' Earth-globe?
64.32: But when ended the term, and wisht-for light of the day-tide
64.33: Uprose, flocks to the house in concourse mighty, convened,
64.34: Thessaly all, with glad assembly the Palace fulfilling:
64.35: Presents afore they bring, and joy in faces declare they.
64.36: Cieros abides a desert: they quit Phthiotican Tempe,
64.37: Homesteads of Crannon-town, eke bulwarkt walls Larissa;
64.38: Meeting at Pharsalus, and roof Pharsalian seeking.
64.39: None will the fields now till; soft wax all necks the oxen,
64.40: Never the humble vine is purged by curve of the rake-tooth,
64.41: Never a pruner's hook thins out the shade of the tree-tufts,
64.42: Never a bull up-plows broad glebe with bend of the coulter,
64.43: Over whose point unuse displays the squalor of rust-stain.
64.44: But in the homestead's heart, where'er that opulent palace
64.45: Hides a retreat, all shines with splendour of gold and of silver.
64.46: Ivory blanches the seats, bright gleam the flagons a-table,
64.47: All of the mansion joys in royal riches and grandeur.
64.48: But for the Diva's use bestrewn is the genial bedstead,
64.49: Hidden in midmost stead, and its polisht framework of Indian
64.50: Tusk underlies its cloth empurpled by juice of the dye-shell.
64.51: This be a figured cloth with forms of manhood primeval
64.52: Showing by marvel-art the gifts and graces of heroes.
64.53: Here upon Dia's strand wave-resonant, ever-regarding
64.54: Theseus borne from sight outside by fleet of the fleetest,
64.55: Stands Ariadne with heart full-filled with furies unbated,
64.56: Nor can her sense as yet believe she 'spies the espied,
64.57: When like one that awakes new roused from slumber deceptive,
64.58: Sees she her hapless self lone left on loneliest sandbank:
64.59: While as the mindless youth with oars disturbeth the shallows,
64.60: Casts to the windy storms what vows he vainly had vowed.
64.61: Him through the sedges afar the sad-eyed maiden of Minos,
64.62: Likest a Bacchant-girl stone-carven, (O her sorrow!)
64.63: 'Spies, a-tossing the while on sorest billows of love-care.
64.64: Now no more on her blood-hued hair fine fillets retains she,
64.65: No more now light veil conceals her bosom erst hidden,
64.66: Now no more smooth zone contains her milky-hued paplets:
64.67: All gear dropping adown from every part of her person
64.68: Thrown, lie fronting her feet to the briny wavelets a sea-toy.
64.69: But at such now no more of her veil or her fillet a-floating
64.70: Had she regard: on you, Theseus! all of her heart-strength,
64.71: All of her sprite, her mind, forlorn, were evermore hanging.
64.72: Ah, sad soul, by grief and grievance driven beside you,
64.73: Sowed Erycina first those brambly cares in thy bosom,
64.74: What while issuing fierce with will enstarkened, Theseus
64.75: Forth from the  bow-bent shore Piraean putting a-seawards
64.76: Reacht the Gortynian roofs where dwelt the injurious Monarch.
64.77: For 'twas told of yore how forced by pestilence cruel,
64.78: Eke as a blood rite due for the Androgeonian murder,
64.79: Many a chosen youth and the bloom of damsels unmarried
64.80: Food for the Minotaur, Cecropia was wont to befurnish.
64.81: Seeing his narrow walls in such wise vexed with evils,
64.82: Theseus of freest will for dear-loved Athens his body
64.83: Offered a victim so that no more to Crete be deported
64.84: Lives by Cecropia doomed to burials burying nowise;
64.85: Then with a swifty ship and soft breathed breezes a-stirring,
64.86: Sought he Minos the Haughty where homed in proudest of Mansions.
64.87: Him as with yearning glance forthright espied the royal
64.88: Maiden, whom pure chaste couch aspiring delicate odours
64.89: Cherisht, in soft embrace of a mother comforted all-whiles,
64.90: (E'en as the myrtles begot by the flowing floods of Eurotas,
64.91: Or as the tincts distinct brought forth by breath of the springtide)
64.92: Never the burning lights of her eyes from gazing upon him
64.93: Turned she, before fierce flame in all her body conceived she
64.94: Down in its deepest depths and burning within her marrow.
64.95: Ah, with unmitigate heart exciting wretchedmost furies,
64.96: You, Boy sacrosanct! man's grief and gladness commingling,
64.97: You too of Golgos Queen and Lady of leafy Idalium,
64.98: Whelm'd you in what manner waves that maiden fantasy-fired,
64.99: All for a blond-haired youth suspiring many a singulf!
64.100: Whiles how dire was the dread she dreed in languishing heart-strings;
64.101: How yet more, ever more, with golden splendour she paled!
64.102: Whenas yearning to mate his might with the furious monster
64.103: Theseus braved his death or sought the prizes of praises.
64.104: Then of her gifts to gods not ingrate, nor profiting naught,
64.105: Promise with silent lip, addressed she timidly vowing.
64.106: For as an oak that shakes on topmost summit of Taurus
64.107: Its boughs, or cone-growing pine from bole bark resin exuding,
64.108: Whirlwind of passing might that twists the stems with its storm-blasts,
64.109: Uproots, deracinates, forthright its trunk to the farthest,
64.110: Prone falls, shattering wide what lies in line of its downfall,—
64.111: Thus was that wildling flung by Theseus and vanquisht of body,
64.112: Vainly tossing its horns and goring the wind to no purpose.
64.113: Thence with abounding praise returned he, guiding his footsteps,
64.114: While a fine drawn thread checked steps in wander abounding,
64.115: Lest when issuing forth of the winding maze labyrinthine
64.116: Baffled become his track by inobservable error.
64.117: But for what cause should I, from early subject digressing,
64.118: Tell of the daughter who the face of her sire unseeing,
64.119: Eke her sister's embrace nor less her mother's endearments,
64.120: Who in despair bewept her hapless child that so gladly
64.121: Chose before every and each the lively wooing of Theseus?
64.122: Or how borne by the ship to the yeasting shore-line of Dia
64.123: Came she? or how when bound her eyes in bondage of slumber
64.124: Left her that chosen mate with mind unmindful departing?
64.125: Often (they tell) with heart inflamed by fiery fury
64.126: Poured she shrilling of shrieks from deepest depths of her bosom;
64.127: Now she would sadly scale the broken faces of mountains,
64.128: Whence she might overglance the boundless boiling of billows,
64.129: Then she would  rush to bestem the salt-plain's quivering wavelet
64.130: And from her ankles bare the dainty garment uplifting,
64.131: Spoke she these words ('tis said) from sorrow's deepest abysses,
64.132: While from her tear-drencht face outburst cold shivering sobs.
64.133: "Thus from my patrial shore, O traitor, hurried to exile,
64.134: Me on a lonely strand hast left, perfidious Theseus?
64.135: Thus wise farest, despite the godhead of Deities spurned,
64.136: (Reckless, alas!) to your home convoying perjury-curses?
64.137: Naught, then, ever availed that mind of cruelest counsel
64.138: Alter? No saving grace in you was evermore ready,
64.139: That to have pity on me vouchsafed your pitiless bosom?
64.140: Nevertheless not in past time such were the promises wordy
64.141: Lavished; nor such hopes to me the hapless were bidden;
64.142: But the glad married joys, the longed-for pleasures of wedlock.
64.143: All now empty and vain, by breath of the breezes bescattered!
64.144: Now, let woman no more trust her to man when he sweareth,
64.145: Ne'er let her hope to find or truth or faith in his pleadings,
64.146: Who when lustful thought forelooks to somewhat attaining,
64.147: Never an oath they fear, shall spare no promise to promise.
64.148: Yet no sooner they sate all lewdness and lecherous fancy,
64.149: Nothing remember of words and reck they naught of fore-swearing.
64.150: Certes, you did I snatch from midmost whirlpool of ruin
64.151: Deadly, and held it cheap loss of a brother to suffer
64.152: Rather than fail your need (O false!) at hour the supremest.
64.153: Therefore my limbs are doomed to be torn of birds, and of ferals
64.154: Prey, nor shall upheapt Earth afford a grave to my body.
64.155: Say me, what lioness bare you 'neath lone rock of the desert?
64.156: What sea spued you conceived from out the spume of his surges!
64.157: What manner Syrt, what ravening Scylla, what vasty Charybdis?
64.158: you who for sweet life saved such meeds are lief of returning!
64.159: If never willed your breast with me to mate you in marriage,
64.160: Hating the savage law decreed by primitive parent,
64.161: Still of your competence 'twas within your household to home me,
64.162: Where I might serve as slave in gladsome service familiar,
64.163: Laving your snow-white feet in clearest chrystalline waters
64.164: Or with its purpling gear your couch in company strewing.
64.165: Yet for what cause should I complain in vain to the winds that unknow me,
64.166: (I so beside me with grief!) which ne'er of senses endued
64.167: Hear not the words sent forth nor aught avail they to answer?
64.168: Now be his course well-nigh engaged in midway of ocean,
64.169: Nor any mortal shape appears in barrens of sea-wrack.
64.170: Thus at the latest hour with insults over-sufficient
64.171: E'en to my plaints fere Fate begrudges ears that would hear me.
64.172: Jupiter! Lord of All-might, Oh would in days that are bygone
64.173: Ne'er had Cecropian poops toucht ground at Gnossian foreshore,
64.174: Nor to the unconquered Bull that tribute direful conveying
64.175: Had the false Seaman bound to Cretan island his hawser,
64.176: Nor had yon evil wight, 'neath shape the softest hard purpose
64.177: Hiding, enjoyed repose within our mansion beguested!
64.178: Whither can wend I now? What hope lends help to the lost one?
64.179: Idomenean mounts shall I scale? Ah, parted by whirlpools
64.180: Widest, yon truculent main where yields it power of passage?
64.181: Aid of my sire can I crave? Whom I willing abandoned,
64.182: Treading in tracks of a youth bewrayed with blood of a brother!
64.183: Can I console my soul with the helpful love of a helpmate
64.184: Who flies me with pliant oars, flies overbounding the sea-depths?
64.185: Nay, if this Coast I quit, this lone isle lends me no roof-tree,
64.186: Nor aught issue allows begirt by billows of Ocean:
64.187: Nowhere is path for flight: none hope shows: all things are silent:
64.188: All be a desolate waste: all makes display of destruction.
64.189: Yet never close these eyes in latest languor of dying,
64.190: Ne'er from my wearied frame go forth slow-ebbing my senses,
64.191: Ere from the Gods just doom implore I, treason-betrayed,
64.192: And with my breath supreme firm faith of Celestials invoke I.
64.193: Therefore, O you who 'venge man's deed with penalties direful,
64.194: Eumenides! aye wont to bind with viperous hairlocks
64.195: Foreheads,—Oh, deign outspeak fierce wrath from bosom outbreathing,
64.196: Hither, Oh hither, speed, and lend you all ear to my grievance,
64.197: Which now sad I (alas!) outpour from innermost vitals
64.198: Maugre my will, sans help, blind, fired with furious madness.
64.199: And, as indeed all spring from veriest core of my bosom,
64.200: Suffer you not the cause of grief and woe to evanish;
64.201: But with the Will wherewith could Theseus leave me in loneness,
64.202: Goddesses! bid that Will lead him, lead his, to destruction."
64.203: E'en as she thus poured forth these words from anguish of bosom,
64.204: And for this cruel deed, distracted, sued she for vengeance,
64.205: Nodded the Ruler of Gods Celestial, matchless of All-might,
64.206: When at the gest earth-plain and horrid spaces of ocean
64.207: Trembled, and every sphere rockt stars and planets resplendent.
64.208: Meanwhile Theseus himself, obscured in blindness of darkness
64.209: As to his mind, dismiss'd from breast oblivious all things
64.210: Erewhile enjoined and held hereto in memory constant,
64.211: Nor for his saddened sire the gladness-signals uphoisting
64.212: Heralded safe return within sight of the Erechthean harbour.
64.213: For 'twas told of yore, when from walls of the Virginal Deess
64.214: Aegeus speeding his son, to the care of breezes committed,
64.215: Thus with a last embrace to the youth spoke words of commandment:
64.216: "Son! far nearer my heart (you alone) than life of the longest,
64.217: Son, I perforce dismiss to doubtful, dangerous chances,
64.218: Lately restored to me when eld draws nearest his ending,
64.219: Since such fortune in me, and in you such boiling of valour
64.220: Tear you away from me so loath, whose eyes in their languor
64.221: Never are sated with sight of my son, all-dearest of figures.
64.222: Nor will I send you forth with joy that gladdens my bosom,
64.223: Nor will I suffer you show boon signs of favouring Fortune,
64.224: But from my soul I'll first express an issue of sorrow,
64.225: Soiling my hoary hairs with dust and ashes commingled;
64.226: Then will I hang stained sails fast-made to the wavering yard-arms,
64.227: So shall our mourning thought and burning torture of spirit
64.228: Show by the dark sombre-dye of Iberian canvas spread.
64.229: But, grant me the grace Who dwells in Sacred Itone,
64.230: (And our issue to guard and ward the seats of Erechtheus
64.231: Sware She) that if your right is besprent with blood of the Man-Bull,
64.232: Then do you so-wise act, and stored in memory's heart-core
64.233: Dwell these mandates of me, no time their traces untracing.
64.234: Dip, when first shall arise our hills to gladden your eye-glance,
64.235: Down from your every mast the ill-omened vestments of mourning,
64.236: Then let the twisten ropes upheave the whitest of canvas,
64.237: Wherewith splendid shall gleam the tallest spars of the top-mast,
64.238: These seeing sans delay with joy exalting my spirit
64.239: Well shall I wot boon Time sets you returning before me."
64.240: Such were the mandates which stored at first in memory constant
64.241: Faded from Theseus' mind like mists, compelled by the whirlwind,
64.242: Fleet from aerial crests of mountains hoary with snow-drifts.
64.243: But as the sire had sought the citadel's summit for outlook,
64.244: Wasting his anxious eyes with tear-floods evermore flowing,
64.245: Forthright e'en as he saw the sail-gear darkened with dye-stain,
64.246: Headlong himself flung he from the sea-cliff's pinnacled summit
64.247: Holding his Theseus lost by doom of pitiless Fortune.
64.248: Thus as he came to the home funest, his roof-tree paternal,
64.249: Theseus (vaunting the death), what dule to the maiden of Minos
64.250: Dealt with unminding mind so dree'd he similar dolour.
64.251: She too gazing in grief at the kelson vanishing slowly,
64.252: Self-wrapt, manifold cares revolved in spirit perturbed.
64.253: But from the further side came flitting bright-faced Iacchus
64.254: Girded by Satyr-crew and Nysa-reared Sileni
64.255: Burning with love unto thee (Ariadne!) and greeting thy presence.
64.257: Who flocking eager to fray did rave with infuriate spirit,
64.258: "Evoe" frenzying loud, with heads at "Evoe” rolling.
64.259: Brandisht some of the maids their thyrsi sheathed of spear-point,
64.260: Some snatcht limbs and joints of sturlings rended to pieces,
64.261: These girt necks and waists with writhing bodies of vipers,
64.262: Those with the gear enwombed in crates dark orgies ordained—
64.263: Orgies that ears profane must vainly lust for o'er hearing—
64.264: Others with palms on high smote hurried strokes on the cymbal,
64.265: Or from the polisht brass woke thin-toned tinkling music,
64.266: While from the many there boomed and blared hoarse blast of the horn-trump,
64.267: And with its horrid skirl loud shrilled the barbarous bag-pipe
64.268: Showing such varied forms, that richly-decorated couch-cloth
64.269: Folded in strait embrace the bedding drapery-veiled.
64.270: This when the Thessalan youths had eyed with eager inspection
64.271: Fulfilled, place they began to provide for venerate Godheads,
64.272: Even as Zephyrus' breath, seas couching placid at dawn-tide,
64.273: Roughens, then stings and spurs the wavelets slantingly fretted—
64.274: Rising Aurora the while 'neath Sol the wanderer's threshold—
64.275: Tardy at first they flow by the clement breathing of breezes
64.276: Urged, and echo the shores with soft-toned ripples of laughter,
64.277: But as the winds wax high so waves wax higher and higher,
64.278: Flashing and floating afar to outswim morn's purpurine splendours,—
64.279: So did the crowd fare forth, the royal vestibule leaving,
64.280: And to their house each wight with vaguing paces departed.
64.281: After their wending, the first, foremost from Pelion's summit,
64.282: Chiron came to the front with woodland presents surcharged:
64.283: Whatso of blooms and flowers bring forth Thessalian uplands
64.284: Mighty with mountain crests, whate'er of riverine lea flowers
64.285: Reareth Favonius' air, bud-breeding, tepidly breathing,
64.286: All in his hands brought he, unseparate in woven garlands,
64.287: Whereat laughed the house as soothed by pleasure of perfume.
64.288: Presently Péneus appears, deserting verdurous Tempe—
64.289: Tempe girt by her belts of greenwood ever impending,
64.290: Left for the Mamonides with frequent dances to worship—
64.291: Nor is he empty of hand, for bears he tallest of beeches
64.292: Deracinate, and bays with straight boles lofty and stately,
64.293: Not without nodding plane-tree nor less the flexible sister
64.294: Fire-slain Phaëton left, and not without cypresses airy.
64.295: These in a line wide-broke set he, the Mansion surrounding,
64.296: So by the soft leaves screened, the porch might flourish in verdure.
64.297: Follows hard on his track with active spirit Prometheus,
64.298: Bearing extenuate sign of penalties suffer'd in by-gones.
64.299: Paid erewhiles what time fast-bound as to every member,
64.300: Hung he in carkanet slung from the Scythian rocktor.
64.301: Last did the Father of Gods with his sacred spouse and his offspring,
64.302: Proud from the Heavens proceed, thee leaving (Phoebus) in loneness,
64.303: Lone wi' thy sister twin who haunteth mountains of Idrus:
64.304: For that the Virgin spurned as thou the person of Peleus,
64.305: Nor Thetis' nuptial torch would greet by act of her presence.
64.306: When they had leaned their limbs upon snowy benches reposing,
64.307: Tables largely arranged with various viands were garnisht.
64.308: But, ere opened the feast, with infirm gesture their semblance
64.309: Shaking, the Parcae fell to chaunting veridique verses.
64.310: Robed were their tremulous frames all o'er in muffle of garments
64.311: Bright-white, purple of hem enfolding heels in its edges;
64.312: Snowy the fillets that bound heads aged by many a year-tide,
64.313: And, as their wont aye was, their hands plied labour unceasing.
64.314: Each in her left upheld with soft fleece clothed a distaff,
64.315: Then did the right that drew forth thread with upturn of fingers
64.316: Gently fashion the yarn which deftly twisted by thumb-ball
64.317: Speeded the spindle poised by thread-whorl perfect of polish;
64.318: Thus as the work was wrought, the lengths were trimmed wi' the fore-teeth,
64.319: While to their thin, dry lips stuck wool-flecks severed by biting,
64.320: Which at the first outstood from yarn-hanks evenly fine-drawn.
64.321: Still at their feet in front soft fleece-flecks white as the snow-flake
64.322: Lay in the trusty guard of wickers woven in withies.
64.323: Always a-carding the wool, with clear-toned voices resounding
64.324: Told they such lots as these in song divinely directed,
64.325: Chaunts which none after-time shall 'stablish falsehood-convicted.
64.326: O who by virtues great all highmost  honours enhancest,
64.327: Guard of Emáthia-land, most famous made by thine offspring,
64.328: Take what the Sisters deign this gladsome day to disclose thee,
64.329: Oracles soothfast told,—And ye, by Destiny followed,
64.330: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.331: Soon to thy sight shall rise, their fond hopes bringing to bridegrooms,
64.332: Hesperus: soon shall come thy spouse with planet auspicious,
64.333: Who shall thy mind enbathe with a love that softens the spirit,
64.334: And as thyself shall prepare for sinking in languorous slumber,
64.335: Under thy neck robust, soft arms dispreading as pillow.
64.336: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.337: Never a house like this such loves as these hath united,
64.338: Never did love conjoin by such-like covenant lovers,
64.339: As th'according tie Thetis deigned in concert wi' Peleus.
64.340: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.341: Born of yon twain shall come Achilles guiltless of fear-sense,
64.342: Known by his forceful breast and ne'er by back to the foeman,
64.343: Who shall at times full oft in doubtful contest of race-course
64.344: Conquer the fleet-foot doe with slot-tracks smoking and burning.
64.345: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.346: None shall with him compare, howe'er war-doughty a hero,
64.347: Whenas the Phrygian rills flow deep with bloodshed of Teucer,
64.348: And beleaguering the walls of Troy with longest of warfare
64.349: He shall the works lay low, third heir of Pelops the perjured.
64.350: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.351: His be the derring-do and deeds of valour egregious,
64.352: Often mothers shall own at funeral-rites of their children,
64.353: What time their hoary hairs from head in ashes are loosened,
64.354: And wi' their hands infirm thay smite their bosoms loose duggèd.
64.355: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.356: For as the toiling hind bestrewing denseness of corn-stalks
64.357: Under the broiling sun mows grain-fields yellow to harvest,
64.358: So shall his baneful brand strew earth with corpses of Troy-born.
64.359: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.360: Aye to his valorous worth attest shall wave of Scamander
64.361: Which unto Hellè-Sea fast flowing ever dischargeth,
64.362: Straiter whose course shall grow by up-heaped barrage of corpses,
64.363: While in his depths runs warm his stream with slaughter commingled.
64.364: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.365: Witness in fine shall be the victim rendered to death-stroke,
64.366: Whenas the earthern tomb on lofty tumulus builded
64.367: Shall of the stricken maid receive limbs white as the snow-flake.
64.368: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.369: For when at last shall Fors to weary Achaians her fiat
64.370: Deal, of Dardanus-town to burst Neptunian fetters,
64.371: Then shall the high-reared tomb stand bathed with Polyxena's life-blood,
64.372: Who, as the victim doomed to fall by the double-edged falchion,
64.373: Forward wi' hams relaxt shall smite a body beheaded.
64.374: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.375: Wherefore arise, ye pair, conjoin loves ardently longed-for,
64.376: Now doth the groom receive with happiest omen his goddess,
64.377: Now let the bride at length to her yearning spouse be delivered.
64.378: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.379: Neither the nurse who comes at dawn to visit her nursling
64.380: E'er shall avail her neck to begird with yesterday's ribband.
64.381: [Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 spindles.]
64.382: Nor shall the mother's soul for ill-matcht daughter a-grieving
64.383: Lose by a parted couch all hopes of favourite grandsons.
64.384: Speed ye, the well-spun woof out-drawing, speed ye, 0 Spindles.
64.385: Thus in the bygone day Peleus' fate foretelling
64.386: Chaunted from breasts divine prophetic verse the Parcae.
64.387: For that the pure chaste homes of heroes to visit in person
64.388: Oft-tide the Gods, and themselves to display where mortals were gathered,
64.389: Wont were the Heavenlies while none human piety spurned.
64.390: Often the Deities' Sire, in fulgent temple a-dwelling,
64.391: Whenas in festal days received he his annual worship,
64.392: Looked upon hundreds of bulls felled prone on pavement before him.
64.393: Full oft Liber who roamed from topmost peak of Parnassus
64.394: Hunted his howling host, his Thyiads with tresses dishevelled.
64.395: Then with contending troops from all their city outflocking
64.396: Gladly the Delphians hailed their God with smoking of altars.
64.397: Often in death-full war and bravest of battle, or Mavors
64.398: Or rapid Triton's Queen or eke the Virgin Rhamnusian,
64.399: Bevies of weaponed men exhorting, proved their presence.
64.400: But from the time when earth was stained with unspeakable scandals
64.401: And forth fro' greeding breasts of all men justice departed,
64.402: Then did the brother drench his hands in brotherly bloodshed,
64.403: Stinted the son in heart to mourn decease of his parents,
64.404: Longèd the sire to sight his first-born's funeral convoy
64.405: So more freely the flower of step-dame-maiden to rifle;
64.406: After that impious Queen her guiltless son underlying,
64.407: Impious, the household gods with crime ne'er dreading to sully—
64.408: All things fair and nefand being mixt in fury of evil
64.409: Turned from ourselves avert the great goodwill of the Godheads.
64.410: Wherefor they nowise deign our human assemblies to visit,
64.411: Nor do they suffer themselves be met in light of the day-tide.

65.1: Albeit care that consumes, with dule assiduous grieving,
65.2: Me from the Learnèd Maids (Hortalus!) ever seclude,
65.3: Nor can avail sweet births of the Muses thou to deliver
65.4: Thought o' my mind; (so much floats it on flooding of ills:
65.5: For that the Lethe-wave upsurging of late from abysses,
65.6: Lavèd my brother's foot, paling with pallor of death,
65.7: He whom the Trojan soil, Rhoetean shore underlying,
65.8: Buries for ever and aye, forcibly snatched from our sight.
65.10: I can address; no more shall I hear thee tell of thy doings,
65.11: Say, shall I never again, brother all liefer than life,
65.12: Sight thee henceforth? But I will surely love thee for ever
65.13: Ever what songs I sing saddened shall be by thy death;
65.14: Such as the Daulian bird 'neath gloom of shadowy frondage
65.15: Warbles, of Itys lost ever bemoaning the lot.)
65.16: Yet amid grief so great to thee, my Hortalus, send I
65.17: These strains sung to a mode borrowed from Battiades;
65.18: Lest shouldest weet of me thy words, to wandering wind-gusts
65.19: Vainly committed, perchance forth of my memory flowed—
65.20: As did that apple sent for a furtive giftie by wooer,
65.21: In the chaste breast of the Maid hidden a-sudden out-sprang;
65.22: For did the hapless forget when in loose-girt garment it lurkèd,
65.23: Forth would it leap as she rose, scared by her mother's approach,
65.24: And while coursing headlong, it rolls far out of her keeping,
65.25: O'er the triste virgin's brow flushes the conscious blush.

66.1: He who every light of the sky world's vastness inspected,
66.2: He who mastered in mind risings and settings of stars,
66.3: How of the fast rising sun obscured be the fiery splendours,
66.4: How at the seasons assured vanish the planets from view,
66.5: How Diana to lurk thief-like 'neath Latmian stone-fields,
66.6: Summoned by sweetness of Love, comes from her aëry gyre;
66.7: That same Cónon espied among lights Celestial shining
66.8: Me, Berenice's Hair, which, from her glorious head,
66.9: Fulgent in brightness afar, to many a host of the Godheads
66.10: Stretching her soft smooth arms she vowed to devoutly bestow,
66.11: What time strengthened by joy of new-made wedlock the monarch
66.12: Bounds of Assyrian land hurried to plunder and pill;
66.13: Bearing of nightly strife new signs and traces delicious,
66.14: Won in the war he waged virginal trophies to win.
66.15: Loathsome is Venus to all new-paired? Else why be the parents'
66.16: Pleasure frustrated aye by the false flow of tears
66.17: Poured in profusion amid illuminate genial chamber?
66.18: Nay not real the 'groans; ever so help me the Gods!
66.19: This truth taught me my Queen by force of manifold 'plainings
66.20: After her new groom hied facing the fierceness of fight.
66.21: Yet so thou mournedst not for a bed deserted of husband,
66.22: As for a brother beloved wending on woefullest way?
66.23: How was the marrow of thee consumedly wasted by sorrow!
66.24: So clean forth of thy breast, rackt with solicitous care,
66.25: Mind fled, sense being reft! But I have known thee for certain
66.26: E'en from young virginal years lofty of spirit to be.
66.27: Hast thou forgotten the feat whose greatness won thee a royal
66.28: Marriage—a deed so prow, never a prower was dared?
66.29: Yet how sad was the speech thou spakest, thy husband farewelling!
66.30: (Jupiter!) Often thine eyes wiping with sorrowful hand!
66.31: What manner God so great thus changed thee? Is it that lovers
66.32: Never will tarry afar parted from person beloved?
66.33: Then unto every God on behalf of thy helpmate, thy sweeting,
66.34: Me thou gayest in vow, not without bloodshed of bulls,
66.35: If he be granted return, and long while nowise delaying,
66.36: Captive Asia he add unto Egyptian bounds.
66.37: Now for such causes I, enrolled in host of the Heavens,
66.38: By a new present, discharge promise thou madest of old:
66.39: Maugrè my will, 0 Queen, my place on thy head I relinquished,
66.40: Maugrè my will, I attest, swearing by thee and thy head;
66.41: Penalty due shall befall whoso makes oath to no purpose.
66.42: Yet who assumes the vaunt forceful as iron to be?
66.43: E'en was that mount o'erthrown, though greatest in universe, where through
66.44: Thía's illustrious race speeded its voyage to end,
66.45: Whenas the Medes brought forth new sea, and barbarous youth-hood
66.46: Urged an Armada to swim traversing middle-Athos.
66.47: What can be done by Hair when such things yield them to Iron?
66.48: Jupiter! Grant Chalybon perish the whole of the race,
66.49: Eke who in primal times ore seeking under the surface
66.50: Showed th' example, and spalled iron however so hard.
66.51: Shortly before I was shorn my sister tresses bewailèd
66.52: Lot of me, e'en as the sole brother to Memnon the Black,
66.53: Winnowing upper air wi' feathers flashing and quiv'ring,
66.54: Chloris' wing-borne steed, came before Arsinoë,
66.55: Whence upraising myself he flies through aëry shadows,
66.56: And in chaste Venus' breast drops he the present he bears.
66.57: Eke Zephyritis had sent, for the purpose trusted, her bondsman,
66.58: Settler of Grecian strain on the Canopian strand.
66.59: So willed various Gods, lest sole 'mid lights of the Heavens
66.60: Should Ariadne's crown taken from temples of her
66.61: Glitter in gold, but we not less shine fulgent in splendour,
66.62: We the consecrate spoils shed by a blond-hued head,
66.63: Even as weeping-wet sought I the fanes of Celestials
66.64: Placed me the Goddess a new light amid star-lights of old:
66.65: For with Virgo in touch and joining the furious Lion's
66.66: Radiance with Callisto, maid of Lyc´on beloved,
66.67: Wind I still to the west, conducting tardy Boötes,
66.68: Who unwilling and slow must into Ocean merge.
66.69: Yet though press me o'night the pacing footprints of Godheads,
66.70: Tethys, hoary of hair, ever regains me by day.
66.71: (Lend me thy leave to speak such words, Rhamnusian Virgin,
66.72: Verities like unto these never in fear will I veil;
66.73: Albeit every star asperse me with enemy's censure,
66.74: Secrets in soothfast heart hoarded perforce I reveal.)
66.75: Nowise gladdens me so this state as absence torments me,
66.76: Absence doomëd for aye ta'en fro' my mistress's head,
66.77: Where I was wont (though she such cares unknew in her girlhood)
66.78: Many a thousand scents, Syrian unguents, to sip.
66.79: Now do you pair conjoined by the longed-for light of the torches,
66.80: Earlier yield not selves unto unanimous wills
66.81: Nor wi' the dresses doft your barèd nipples encounter,
66.82: Ere shall yon onyx-vase pour me libations glad,
66.83: Onyx yours, ye that seek only rights of virtuous bed-rite.
66.84: But who yieldeth herself unto advowtry impure,
66.85: Ah! may her loathed gifts in light dust uselessly soak,
66.86: For of unworthy sprite never a gift I desire.
66.87: Rather, 0 new-mated brides, be concord aye your companion,
66.88: Ever let constant love dwell in the dwellings of you.
66.89: Yet when thou sightest, 0 Queen, the Constellations, I pray thee,
66.90: Every festal day Venus the Goddess appease;
66.91: Nor of thy unguent-gifts allow myself to be lacking,
66.92: Nay, do thou rather add largeliest increase to boons.
66.93: Would but the stars down fall! Could I of my Queen be the hair-lock,
66.94: Neighbour to Hydrochois e'en let Oarion shine.

67.1: 0 to the gentle spouse right dear, right dear to his parent,
67.2: Hail, and with increase fair Jupiter lend thee his aid,
67.3: Door, 'tis said wast fain kind service render to Balbus
67.4: Erst while, long as the house by her old owner was held;
67.5: Yet wast rumoured again to serve a purpose malignant,
67.6: After the elder was stretched, thou being oped for a bride.
67.7: Come, then, tell us the why in thee such change be reported
67.8: That to thy lord hast abjured faithfulness owed of old?
67.9: Never (so chance I to please Caeci1ius owning me now-a-days!)
67.10: Is it my own default, how so they say it be mine;
67.11: Nor can any declare aught sin by me was committed.
67.12: Yet it is so declared (Quintus!) by fable of folk;
67.13: Who, whenever they find things done no better than should be,
67.14: Come to me outcrying all:—"Door, the default is thine own!"
67.15: This be never enough for thee one-worded to utter,
67.16: But in such way to deal, each and all sense it and see.
67.17: What shall I do? None asks, while nobody troubles to know.
67.18: Willing are we? unto us stay not thy saying to say.
67.19: First let me note that the maid to us committed (assert they)
67.20: Was but a fraud: her mate never a touch of her had,
67.22: But that a father durst dishonour the bed of his first-born,
67.23: Folk all swear, and the house hapless with incest bewray;
67.24: Or that his impious mind was blunt with fiery passion
67.25: Or that his impotent son sprang from incapable seed.
67.26: And to be sought was one with nerve more nervous endowèd,
67.27: Who could better avail zone of the virgin to loose.
67.28: 'Sooth, of egregious sire for piety wondrous, thou tellest,
67.29: Who in the heart of his son lief was . . . !
67.30: Yet professed herself not only this to be knowing,
67.31: Brixia-town that lies under the Cycnean cliff,
67.32: Traversed by Mella-stream's soft-flowing yellow-hued current,
67.33: Brixia, Vérona's mother, I love for my home.
67.34: Eke of Posthumius' loves and Cornelius too there be tattle,
67.35: With whom dared the dame evil advowtry commit.
67.36: Here might somebody ask :—" How, Door, hast mastered such matter?
67.37: Thou that canst never avail threshold of owner to quit,
67.38: Neither canst listen to folk since here fast fixt to the side-posts
67.39: Only one office thou hast, shutting or opening the house."
67.40: Oft have I heard our dame in furtive murmurs o'er telling,
67.41: When with her handmaids alone, these her flagitious deeds,
67.42: Citing fore-cited names for that she never could fancy
67.43: Ever a Door was endow'd either with earlet or tongue.
67.44: Further she noted a wight whose name in public to mention
67.45: Nill I, lest he upraise eyebrows of carroty hue;
67.46: Long is the loon and large the law-suit brought they against him
67.47: Touching a child-bed false, claim of a belly that lied.

68.1: When to me sore opprest by bitter chance of misfortune
68.2: This thy letter thou send'st written wi' blotting of tears,
68.3: So might I save thee flung by spuming billows of ocean,
68.4: Shipwreckt, rescuing life snatcht from the threshold of death;
68.5: Eke neither Venus the Holy to rest in slumber's refreshment
68.6: Grants thee her grace on couch lying deserted and lone,
68.7: Nor can the Muses avail with dulcet song of old writers
68.8: Ever delight thy mind sleepless in anxious care;
68.9: Grateful be this to my thought since thus thy friend I'm entitled,
68.10: Hence of me seekest thou gifts Muses and Venus can give:
68.11: But that bide not unknown to thee my sorrows (0 Manius!)
68.12: And lest office of host I should be holden to hate,
68.13: Learn how in Fortune's deeps I chance myself to be drownèd,
68.14: Nor fro' the poor rich boons furthermore prithee require.
68.15: What while first to myself the pure-white garment was given,
68.16: Whenas my flowery years flowed in fruition of spring,
68.17: Much I disported enow, nor 'bode I a stranger to Goddess
68.18: Who with our cares is lief sweetness of bitter to mix:
68.19: Yet did a brother's death pursuits like these to my sorrow
68.20: Bid for me cease: Oh, snatcht brother! from wretchedest me.
68.21: Then, yea, thou by thy dying hast broke my comfort, 0 brother;
68.22: Buried together wi' thee lieth the whole of our house;
68.23: Perisht along wi' thyself all gauds and joys of our life-tide,
68.24: Douce love fostered by thee during the term of our days.
68.25: After thy doom of death fro' mind I banishèd wholly
68.26: Studies like these, and all lending a solace to soul;
68.27: Wherefore as to thy writ :—"Verona's home for Catullus
68.28: Bringeth him shame, for there men of superior mark
68.29: Must on a deserted couch fain chafe their refrigerate limbs:"
68.30: Such be no shame (Manius!): rather 'tis matter of ruth.
68.31: Pardon me, then, wilt thou an gifts bereft me by grieving
68.32: These I send not to thee since I avail not present.
68.33: For, that I own not here abundant treasure of writings
68.34: Has for its cause, in Rome dwell I; and there am I homed,
68.35: There be my seat, and there my years are gathered to harvest;
68.36: Out of book-cases galore here am I followed by one.
68.37: This being thus, nill I thou deem 'tis spirit malignant
68.38: Acts in such wise or mind lacking of liberal mood
68.39: That to thy prayer both gifts be not in plenty supplièd:
68.40: Willingly both had I sent, had I the needed supply.
68.41: Nor can I (Goddesses!) hide in what things Allius sent me
68.42: Aid, forbear to declare what was the aidance he deigned:
68.43: Neither shall fugitive Time from centuries ever oblivious
68.44: Veil in the blinds of night friendship he lavisht on me.
68.45: But will I say unto you what you shall say to the many
68.46: Thousands in turn, and make paper, old crone, to proclaim
68.48: And in his death become noted the more and the more,
68.49: Nor let spider on high that weaves her delicate webbing
68.50: Practise such labours o'er Allius' obsolete name.
68.51: For that ye weet right well what care Amathúsia two-faced
68.52: Gave me, and how she dasht every hope to the ground,
68.53: Whenas I burnt so hot as burn Trinacria's rocks or
68.54: Mallia stream that feeds Œtéan Thermopylae;
68.55: Nor did these saddened eyes to be dimmed by assiduous weeping
68.56: Cease, and my cheeks with showers ever in sadness be wet.
68.57: E'en as from aëry heights of mountain springeth a springlet
68.58: Limpidest leaping forth from rocking felted with moss,
68.59: Then having headlong rolled the prone-laid valley downpouring,
68.60: Populous region amid wendeth his gradual way,
68.61: Sweetest solace of all to the sweltering traveller wayworn,
68.62: Whenas the heavy heat fissures the fiery fields;
68.63: Or, as to seamen lost in night of whirlwind a-glooming
68.64: Gentle of breath there comes fairest and favouring breeze,
68.65: Pollux anon being prayed, nor less vows offered to Castor:—
68.66: Such was the aidance to us Manius pleased to afford.
68.67: He to my narrow domains far wider limits laid open,
68.68: He too gave me the house, also he gave me the dame,
68.69: She upon whom both might exert them, partners in love deeds.
68.70: Thither graceful of gait pacing my goddess white-hued
68.71: Came and with gleaming foot on the worn sole of the threshold
68.72: Stood she and prest its slab creakihg her sandals the while;
68.73: E'enso with love enflamed in olden days to her helpmate,
68.75: Sought, but in vain, for ne'er wi' sacrificial blood shed
68.76: Victims appeased the Lords ruling Celestial seats:
68.77: Never may I so joy in aught (Rhamnusian Virgin!)
68.78: That I engage in deed maugrè the will of the Lords.
68.79: How starved altar can crave for gore in piety poured,
68.80: Laodamia learnt taught by the loss of her man,
68.81: Driven perforce to loose the neck of new-wedded help-mate,
68.82: Whenas a winter had gone, nor other winter had come,
68.83: Ere in the long dark nights her greeding love was so sated
68.84: That she had power to live maugrè a marriage broke off,
68.85: Which, as the Parcae knew, too soon was fated to happen
68.86: Should he a soldier sail bound for those llian walls.
68.87: For that by Helena's rape, the Champion-leaders of Argives
68.88: Unto herself to incite Troy had already begun,
68.89: Troy (ah, curst be the name) common tomb of Asia and Europe,
68.90: Troy to sad ashes that turned valour and valorous men!
68.91: Eke to our brother beloved, destruction ever lamented
68.92: Brought she : 0 Brother for aye lost unto wretchedmost me,
68.93: Oh, to thy wretchedmost brother lost the light of his life-tide,
68.94: Buried together wi' thee lieth the whole of our house:
68.95: Perisht along wi' thyself forthright all joys we enjoyèd,
68.96: Douce joys fed by thy love during the term of our days;
68.97: Whom now art tombed so far nor 'mid familiar pavestones
68.98: Nor wi' thine ashes stored near to thy kith and thy kin,
68.99: But in that Troy obscene, that Troy of ill-omen, entombèd
68.100: Holds thee, an alien earth-buried in uttermost bourne.
68.101: Thither in haste so hot ('tis said) from allwhere the Youth-hood
68.102: Grecian, farèd in hosts forth of their hearths and their homes,
68.103: Lest with a stolen punk with fullest of pleasure should Paris
68.104: Fairly at leisure and ease sleep in the pacific bed.
68.105: Such was the hapless chance, most beautiful Laodamia,
68.106: Tare fro' thee dearer than life, dearer than spirit itself,
68.107: Him, that husband, whose love in so mighty a whirlpool of passion
68.108: Whelmed thee absorbed and plunged deep in its gulfy abyss,
68.109: E'en as the Grecians tell hard by Phenéus of Cylléne
68.110: Drained was the marish and dried, forming the fattest of soils,
68.111: Whenas in days long done to delve through marrow of mountains
68.113: What time sure of his shafts he smote Stymphalian monsters
68.114: Slaying their host at the hest dealt by a lord of less worth,
68.115: So might the gateway of Heaven be trodden by more of the godheads,
68.116: Nor might Hébé abide longer to maidenhood doomed.
68.117: Yet was the depth of thy love far deeper than deepest of marish
68.118: Which the hard mistress's yoke taught him so tamely to bear;
68.119: Never was head so dear to a grandsire wasted by life-tide
68.120: Whenas one daughter alone a grandson so tardy had reared,
68.121: Who being found against hope to inherit riches of forbears
68.122: In the well-witnessed Will haply by name did appear,
68.123: And 'spite impious hopes of baffled claimant to kinship
68.124: Startles the Vulturine grip clutching the frost-bitten poll.
68.125: Nor with such rapture e'er joyed his mate of snowy-hued plumage
68.126: Dove-mate, albeit aye wont in her immoderate heat
68.127: Said be the bird to snatch hot kisses with beak ever billing,
68.128: As diddest thou :—yet is Woman multivolent still.
68.129: But thou 'vailedest alone all these to conquer in love-lowe,
68.130: When conjoindd once more unto thy yellow-haired spouse.
68.131: Worthy of yielding to her in naught or ever so little
68.132: Came to the bosom of us she, the fair light of my life,
68.133: Round whom fluttering oft the Love-God hither and thither
68.134: Shone with a candid sheen robed in his safflower dress.
68.135: She though never she bide with one Catullus contented,
68.136: Yet will I bear with the rare thefts of my dame the discreet,
68.137: Lest over-irk I give which still of fools is the fashion.
68.138: Often did Juno eke Queen of the Heavenly host
68.139: Boil wi' the rabidest rage at dire default of a husband
68.140: Learning the manifold thefts of her omnivolent Jove,
68.141: Yet with the Gods mankind 'tis nowise righteous to liken,
68.143: Rid me of graceless task fit for a tremulous sire.
68.144: Yet was she never to me by hand paternal committed
68.145: Whenas she came to my house reeking Assyrian scents;
68.146: Nay, in the darkness of night her furtive favours she deigned me,
68.147: Self-willed taking herself from very mate's very breast.
68.148: Wherefore I hold it enough since given to us and us only
68.149: Boon of that day with Stone whiter than wont she denotes.
68.150: This to thee—all that I can—this offering couched in verses
68.151: (Allius!) as my return give I for service galore;
68.152: So wi' the seabriny rust your name may never be sullied
68.153: This day and that nor yet other and other again.
68.154: Hereto add may the Gods all good gifts, which Themis erewhiles
68.155: Wont on the pious of old from her full store to bestow:
68.156: Blest be the times of the twain, thyself and she who thy life is,
68.157: Also the home wherein dallied we, no less the Dame,
68.158: Anser to boot who first of mortals brought us together,
68.159: Whence from beginning all good Fortunes that blest us were born.
68.160: Lastly than every else one dearer than self and far dearer,
68.161: Light of my life who alive living to me can endear.

69.1: Wonder not blatantly why no woman shall ever be willing
69.2: (Rufus!) her tender thigh under thyself to bestow,
69.3: Not an thou tempt her full by bribes of the rarest garments,
69.4: Or by the dear delights gems the pellucidest deal.
69.5: Harms thee an ugly tale wherein of thee is recorded
69.6: Horrible stench of the goat under thine arm-pits be lodged.
69.7: All are in dread thereof; nor wonder this, for 'tis evil
69.8: Beastie, nor damsel fair ever thereto shall succumb.
69.9: So do thou either kill that cruel pest o' their noses,
69.10: Or at their reason of flight blatantly wondering cease.

70.1: Never, my woman oft says, with any of men will she mate be,
70.2: Save wi' my own very self, ask her though Jupiter deign!
70.3: Says she: but womanly words that are spoken to desireful lover
70.4: Ought to be written on wind or upon water that runs.

71.1: An of a goat-stink damned from armpits fusty one suffer,
71.2: Or if a crippling gout worthily any one rack,
71.3: 'Tis that rival o' thine who lief in loves of you meddles,
71.4: And, by a wondrous fate, gains him the twain of such ills.
71.5: For that, oft as he . . . , so oft that penance be two-fold;
71.6: Stifles her stench of goat, he too is kilt by his gout.

72.1: Wont thou to vaunt whilòme of, knowing only Catullus
72.2: (Lesbia!) nor to prefer Jupiter's self to myself.
72.3: Then, too, I loved thee well, not as vulgar wretch his mistress
72.4: But as a father his sons loves and his sons by the law.
72.5: Now have I learnt thee aright; wherefor though burn I the hotter,
72.6: Lighter and viler by far thou unto me hast become.
72.7: "How can this be?" dost ask: 'tis that such injury ever
72.8: Forces the hotter to love, also the less well to will.

73.1: Cease thou of any to hope desirèd boon of well-willing,
73.2: Or deem any shall prove pious and true to his dues.
73.3: Waxes the world ingrate, no deed benevolent profits,
73.4: Nay full oft it irks even offending the more:
73.5: Such is my case whom none maltreats more grievously bitter,
73.6: Than does the man that me held one and only to friend.

74.1: Wont was Gellius hear his uncle rich in reproaches,
74.2: When any ventured aught wanton in word or in deed.
74.3: Lest to him chance such befall, his uncle's consort seduced he,
74.4: And of his uncle himself fashioned an Harpocrates.
74.5: What so he willed did he; and nowdays albe his uncle
74.6: . . . .he, no word ever that uncle shall speak.

75.1: So in devotion to thee lost is the duty self due,
75.2: Nor can I will thee well if best of women thou prove thee,
75.3: Nor can I cease to love, do thou what doings thou wilt.

76.1: If to remember deeds whilòme well done be a pleasure
76.2: Meet for a man who deems all of his dealings be just,
76.3: Nor Holy Faith ever broke nor in whatever his compact
76.4: Sanction of Gods abused better to swindle mankind,
76.5: Much there remains for thee during length of living, Catullus,
76.6: Out of that Love ingrate further to solace thy soul;
76.7: For whatever of good can mortal declare of another
76.8: Or can avail he do, such thou hast said and hast done;
76.9: While to a thankless mind entrusted all of them perisht.
76.10: Why, then, crucify self now with a furthering pain?
76.11: Why not steady thy thoughts and draw thee back from such purpose,
76.12: Ceasing wretched to be maugrè the will of the Gods?
76.13: Difficult 'tis indeed long Love to depose of a sudden,
76.14: Difficult 'tis, yet do e'en as thou deem to be best.
76.15: This be thy safe-guard sole; this conquest needs to be conquered;
76.16: This thou must do, thus act, whether thou cannot or can.
76.17: If an ye have (0 Gods!) aught ruth, or if you for any
76.18: Bring at the moment of death latest assistance to man,
76.19: Look upon me (poor me!) and, should I be cleanly of living,
76.20: Out of my life deign pluck this my so pestilent plague,
76.21: Which as a lethargy o'er mine inmost vitals a-creeping,
76.22: Hath from my bosom expelled all of what joyance it joyed,
76.23: Now will I crave no more she love me e'en as I love her,
76.24: Nor (impossible chance!) ever she prove herself chaste:
76.25: Would I were only healed and shed this fulsome disorder.
76.26: Oh Gods, grant me this boon unto my piety due!

77.1: Rufus, trusted as friend by me, so fruitlessly, vainly,
77.2: (Vainly? nay to my bane and at a ruinous price!)
77.3: Hast thou cajoled me thus, and enfiring innermost vitals,
77.4: Ravished the whole of our good own'd by wretchedest me?
77.5: Ravished; (alas and alas!) of our life thou cruellest cruel
77.6: Venom, (alas and alas!) plague of our friendship and pest.
77.7: Yet must I now lament that lips so pure of the purest
77.8: Damsel, thy slaver foul soiled with filthiest kiss.
77.9: But ne'er hope to escape scot free; for thee shall all ages
77.10: Know, and what thing thou be, Fame, the old crone, shall declare.

78.1: Gallus hath brothers in pair, this owning most beautiful consort,
78.2: While unto that is given also a beautiful son.
78.3: Gallus is charming as man; for sweet loves ever conjoins he,
78.4: So that the charming lad sleep wi' the charmer his lass.
78.5: Gallus is foolish wight, nor self regards he as husband,
78.6: When being uncle how nuncle to cuckold he show.

79.1: Lesbius is beauty-man: why not? when Lesbia wills him
79.2: Better, Catullus, than thee backed by the whole of thy clan.
79.3: Yet may that beauty-man sell all his clan with Catullus,
79.4: An of three noted names greeting salute he can gain.

80.1: How shall I (Gellius!) tell what way lips rosy as thine are
80.2: Come to be bleached and blanched whiter than wintry snow,
80.3: When as thou quittest the house a-morn, and at two after noon-tide
80.4: Roused from quiet repose, wakest for length of the day?
80.5: Certès sure am I not an Rumour rightfully whisper

81.1: Could there never be found in folk so thronging (Juventius!)
81.2: Any one charming thee whom thou couldst fancy to love,
81.3: Save and except that host from deadliest site of Pisaurum,
81.4: Wight than a statue gilt wanner and yellower-hued,
81.5: Whom to thy heart thou takest and whom thou darest before us
81.6: Choose? But villain what deed doest thou little canst wot!

82.1: Quintius! an thou wish that Catullus should owe thee his eyes
82.2: Or aught further if aught dearer can be than his eyes,
82.3: Thou wilt not ravish from him what deems he dearer and nearer
82.4: E'en than his eyes if aught dearer there be than his eyes.

83.1: Lesbia heaps upon me foul words her mate being present;
83.2: Which to that simple soul causes the fullest delight.
83.3: Mule! naught sensest thou: did she forget us in silence,
83.4: Whole she had been; but now what so she rails and she snarls,
83.5: Not only dwells in her thought, but worse and even more risky,
83.6: Wrathful she bides. Which means, she is afire and she fumes.

84.3: What time flattering self he speaks with marvellous purity,
84.4: Clamouring "Hinsidious" loudly as ever he can.
84.5: Deem I thus did his dame and thus-wise Liber his uncle
84.6: Speak, and on spindle-side grandsire and grandmother too.
84.7: Restful reposed all ears when he was sent into Syria,
84.8: Hearing the self-same words softly and smoothly pronouncèd,
84.9: Nor any feared to hear such harshness uttered thereafter,
84.10: Whenas a sudden came message of horrible news,
84.11: Namely th' lonian waves when Arrius thither had wended,

85.1: Hate I, and love I. Haps thou'lt ask me wherefore I do so.
85.2: Wot I not, yet so I do feeling a torture of pain.

86.1: Quintia beautiful seems to the crowd; to me, fair, and tall,
86.2: Straight; and merits as these readily thus I confess,
86.3: But that she is beauteous all I deny, for nothing of lovesome,
86.4: Never a grain of salt, shows in her person so large.
86.5: Lesbia beautiful seems, and when all over she's fairest,
86.6: Any Venus-gift stole she from every one.

87.1: Never a woman could call herself so fondly beloved
87.2: Truly as Lesbia mine has been beloved of myself.
87.3: Never were Truth and Faith so firm in any one compact
87.4: As on the part of me kept I my love to thyself.
87.5: Now is my mind to a pass, my Lesbia, brought by thy treason,

88.1: What may he (Gellius!) do that ever for mother and sister
88.2: Itches and wakes thro' the nights, working wi' tunic bedoffed?
88.3: What may he do who nills his uncle ever be husband?
88.4: Wottest thou how much he ventures of sacrilege-sin?
88.5: Ventures he (0 Gellius!) what ne'er can ultimate Tethys
88.6: Wash from his soul, nor yet Ocean, watery sire.
88.7: For that of sin there's naught wherewith this sin can exceed he

89.1: Gellius is lean: Why not?  For him so easy a mother
89.2: Lives, and a sister so boon, bonny and buxom to boot,
89.3: Uncle so kindly good and all things full of his lady-
89.4: Cousins, how can he cease leanest of lankies to be?
89.5: Albeit, touch he naught save that whose touch is a scandal,
89.6: Soon shall thou find wherefor he be as lean as thou like.

90.1: Born be a Magus, got by Gellius out of his mother
90.2: (Marriage  nefand!) who shall Persian augury learn.
90.3: Needs it a Magus begot of son upon mother who bare him,
90.4: If that impious faith, Persian religion be fact,
90.5: So may their issue adore busy gods with recognised verses
90.6: Melting in altar-flame fatness contained by the caul.

91.1: Not for due cause I hoped to find thee (Gellius!) faithful
91.2: In this saddest our love, love that is lost and forlore,
91.3: Or fro' my wotting thee well or ever believing thee constant,
91.4: Or that thy mind could reject villany ever so vile,
91.5: But that because was she to thyself nor mother nor sister,
91.6: This same damsel whose Love me in its greatness devoured.
91.7: Yet though I had been joined wi' thee by amplest of usance,
91.8: Still could I never believe this was sufficient of cause.
91.9: Thou diddest deem it suffice: so great is thy pleasure in every
91.10: Crime wherein may be found somewhat enormous of guilt.

92.1: Lesbia naggeth at me evermore and ne'er is she silent
92.2: Touching myself: May I die but that by Lesbia I'm loved.
92.3: What be the proof?  I rail and retort like her and revile her
92.4: Carefully, yet may I die but that I love her with love.

93.1: Study I not o'ermuch to please thee (Caesar!) and court thee,
93.2: Nor do I care e'en to know an thou be white or be black.

94.1: Mentula wooeth much: much wooeth he, be assurèd.
94.2: That is, e'en as they say, the Pot gathers leeks for the pot.

95.1: "Zmyrna" begun erstwhile nine harvests past by my Cinna
95.2: Publisht appears when now nine of his winters be gone;
95.3: Thousands fifty of lines meanwhile Hortensius in single
95.5: "Zmyrna" shall travel afar as the hollow breakers of Satrax,
95.6: "Zmyrna" by ages grey lastingly shall be perused.
95.7: But upon Padus' brink shall die Volusius his annals
95.8: And to the mackerel oft loose-fitting jacket afford.
95.9: Dear to my heart are aye the lightest works of my comrade,
95.10: Leave I the mob to enjoy tumidest Antimachus.

96.1: If to the dumb deaf tomb can aught or grateful or pleasing
96.2: (Calvus!) ever accrue rising from out of our dule,
96.3: Wherewith yearning desire renews our loves in the bygone,
96.4: And for long friendships lost many a tear must be shed;
96.5: Certès, never so much for doom of premature death-day
96.6: Must thy Quintilia mourn as she is joyed by thy love.

97.1: Never (so love me the Gods!) deemed I 'twas preference matter
97.2: Or Aemilius' mouth choose I to smell or his . . . .
97.3: Nothing is this more clean, uncleaner nothing that other,
97.4: Yet I ajudge . . . . cleaner and nicer to be;
97.5: For while this one lacks teeth, that one has cubit-long tushes,
97.6: Set in their battered gums favouring a muddy old box,
97.7: Not to say aught of gape like wide-cleft gap of a she-mule
97.8: Whenas in summer-heat wont peradventure to stale.
97.9: Yet has he many a motte and holds himself to be handsome—
97.10: Why wi' the baker's ass is he not bound to the mill?
97.11: Him if a damsel kiss we fain must think she be ready

98.1: Rightly of thee may be said, an of any, (thou stinkingest Victius!)
98.2: Whatso wont we to say touching the praters and prigs.
98.3: Thou wi' that tongue o' thine own, if granted occasion availest
98.4: Brogues of the cowherds to kiss, also their . . . .
98.5: Wouldst thou undo us all with a thorough undoing (0 Victius!)
98.6: Open thy gape :—thereby all shall be wholly undone.

99.1: E'en as thou played'st, from thee snatched I (0 honied Juventius!)
99.2: Kisslet  of savour so sweet sweetest Ambrosia unknows.
99.3: Yet was the theft nowise scot-free, for more than an hour I
99.4: Clearly remember me fixt hanging from crest of the Cross,
99.5: Whatwhile I purged my sin unto thee nor with any weeping
99.6: Tittle of cruel despite such as be thine could I 'bate.
99.7: For that no sooner done thou washed thy liplets with many
99.8: Drops which thy fingers did wipe, using their every joint,
99.9: Lest of our mouths conjoined remain there aught by the contact
99.10: Like unto slaver foul shed by the butterèd bun.
99.11: Further, wretchedmost me betrayed to unfriendliest Love-god
99.12: Never thou ceased'st to pain hurting with every harm,
99.13: So that my taste be turned and kisses ambrosial erstwhile
99.14: Even than hellebore-juice bitterest bitterer grow.
99.15: Seeing such pangs as these prepared for unfortunate lover,
99.16: After this never again kiss will I venture to snatch.

100.2: Love to the death, both swains bloom of the youth Veronese,
100.3: This woo'd brother and that sue'd sister: so might the matter
100.4: Claim to be titled wi' sooth fairest fraternalest tie.
100.5: Whom shall I favour the first?  Thee (Caelius!) for thou hast provèd
100.6: Singular friendship to us shown by the deeds it has done,
100.7: Whenas the flames insane had madded me, firing my marrow:
100.8: Caelius! happy be thou; ever be lusty in love.

101.1: Faring thro' many a folk and plowing many a sea-plain
101.2: These sad funeral-rites (Brother!) to deal thee I come,
101.3: So wi' the latest boons to the dead bestowed I may gift thee,
101.4: And I may vainly address ashes that answer have none,
101.5: Sithence of thee, very thee, to deprive me Fortune behested,
101.6: Woe for thee, Brother forlore!  Cruelly severed fro' me.
101.8: Yet in the meanwhile now what olden usage of forbears
101.9: Brings as the boons that befit mournfullest funeral rites,
101.10: Thine  be these gifts which flow with tear-flood shed by thy brother,
101.11: And,  for ever and aye (Brother!) all hail and farewell.

102.1: If by confiding friend aught e'er be trusted in silence,
102.2: Unto a man whose mind known is for worthiest trust,
102.3: Me shalt thou find no less than such to secrecy oath-bound,
102.4: (Cornelius!) and now hold me an Harpocrates.

103.1: Or, d'ye hear, refund those ten sestertia (Silo!)
103.2: Then be thou e'en at thy will surly and savage o' mood:
103.3: Or, an thou love o'er-well those moneys, prithee no longer
103.4: Prove thee a pimp and withal surly and savage o' mood.

104.1: Canst thou credit that I could avail to revile my life-love,
104.2: She who be dearer to me even than either my eyes?
104.3: Ne'er could I, nor an I could, should I so losingly love her:
104.4: But with Tappo thou dost design every monstrous deed.

105.1: Mentula fain would ascend Pipléan mountain up-mounting:
105.2: Pitch him the Muses down headlong wi' forklets a-hurled.

106.1: When with a pretty-faced boy we see one playing the Crier,
106.2: What can we wot except longs he for selling the same?

107.1: An to one ever accrue any boon he lusted and longed for
107.2: Any time after despair, grateful it comes to his soul.
107.3: Thus 'tis grateful to us nor gold was ever so goodly,
107.4: When thou restorest thyself (Lesbia!) to loving-most me,
107.5: Self thou restorest unhoped, and after despair thou returnest.
107.6: Oh the fair light of a Day noted with notabler white!
107.7: Where lives a happier man than myself or—this being won me—
107.8: Who shall e'er boast that his life brought him more coveted lot?

108.1: If by the verdict o' folk thy hoary old age  (0 Cominius!)
108.2: Filthy with fulsomest lust ever be doomed to the death,
108.3: Make I no manner of doubt but first thy tongue to the worthy
108.4: Ever a foe, cut out, ravening Vulture shall feed;
108.5: Gulp shall the Crow's black gorge those eye-balls dug from their sockets,
108.6: Guts of thee go to the dogs, all that remains to the wolves.

109.1: Gladsome to me, 0 my life, this love whose offer thou deignest
109.2: Between us twain lively and lusty to last soothfast.
109.3: (Great Gods!) grant ye the boon that prove her promises loyal,
109.4: Saying her say in truth spoken with spirit sincere;
109.5: So be it lawful for us to protract through length of our life-tide
109.6: Mutual pact of our love, pledges of holy good will!

110.1: Aufiléna! for aye good lasses are lauded as loyal:
110.2: Price of themselves they accept when they intend to perform.
110.3: All thou promised'st me in belying proves thee unfriendly,
110.4: For never giving and oft taking is deed illy done.
110.5: Either as honest to grant, or modest as never to promise,
110.6: Aufiléna! were fair, but at the gifties to clutch
110.7: Fraudfully, viler seems than greed of greediest harlot
110.8: Who with her every limb maketh a whore of herself.

111.1: Aufiléna! to live content with only one husband,
111.2: Praise is and truest of praise ever bestowed upon wife.
111.3: Yet were it liefer to lie any wise with any for lover,
111.4: Than to be breeder of boys uncle as cousins begat.

112.1: Great th'art (Naso!) as man, nor like thee many in greatness
112.2: Lower themselves (Naso!): great be thou, pathic to boot.

113.1: Pompey first being chosen Consul, twofold (O Cinna!)
113.2: Men for amours were famed:  also when chosen again
113.3: Two they remained; but now is each one grown to a thousand

114.1: For yon Firmian domain not falsely Mentula hight is
114.2: Richard, owning for self so many  excellent things—
114.3: Fish, fur, feather, all kinds, with prairie, corn-land, and ferals.
114.4: All no good: for th' outgoing, income immensely exceeds.
114.5: Therefore his grounds be rich own I, while he's but a pauper.
114.6: Laud we thy land while thou lackest joyance thereof.

115.1: Mentula! masterest thou some thirty acres of grassland
115.2: Full told, forty of field soil; others are sized as the sea.
115.3: Why may he not surpass in his riches any a Crœsus
